docs.title: DSA & LeetCode Preparation Hub
docs.text: Welcome! This hub organizes a focused 45-day SDE prep plan, topic notes, and a place to track solved LeetCode problems.

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• Roadmap: see topic plans under Roadmap
  • Notes: start with Arrays Notes
  • Solved Problems: browse Solved LeetCode

docs.title: How to Use
docs.text:
• Follow the 45-day plan across topics with daily checkboxes
  • Add notes as you learn patterns and techniques
  • Log solved problems with approach and code in solved/*

Happy coding and consistent practice!

docs.title: Mathematics Fundamentals for DSA
docs.text: An intuition-first reference for core mathematics concepts used in Data Structures & Algorithms and LeetCode-style problems. This file focuses on how and why things work, not shortcuts or heavy optimizations.

docs.title: What is a divisor?
docs.text:
A number d is a divisor of n if it divides n completely.

Mathematically:

n % d == 0

docs.title: Intuition
docs.text:
Divisors always come in pairs. If d divides n, then n / d also divides n.

Example for n = 36:

  • 1 × 36
  • 2 × 18
  • 3 × 12
  • 4 × 9
  • 6 × 6

Once d > √n, pairs start repeating. So we only check until √n.

docs.title: Basic Algorithm (Intuitive)
docs.text:
for (int i = 1; i * i <= N; i++) {
    if (N % i == 0) {
        // i is a divisor
        // N / i is also a divisor
    }
}

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Counting divisors
  • Checking prime numbers
  • Factorization problems

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
A prime number has exactly two divisors:

  • 1
  • the number itself

Examples:

  • Prime: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11
  • Not prime: 4 (1,2,4), 6 (1,2,3,6)

docs.title: Intuition
docs.text:
If a number has any divisor other than 1 and itself, it is not prime.

Because divisors come in pairs, we only need to check until √n.

docs.title: Naive Prime Check (Understanding First)
docs.text:
bool isPrime(int n) {
    if (n < 2) return false;
    int cnt = 0;
    for (int i = 1; i * i <= n; i++) {
        if (n % i == 0) {
            cnt++;
            if (i != n / i) cnt++;
        }
    }
    return cnt == 2;
}

docs.title: What is it?
docs.text:
Breaking a number into only prime numbers whose product equals the number.

Example:

60 = 2 × 2 × 3 × 5

docs.title: Intuition
docs.text:
• Try dividing by the smallest possible number
  • Keep dividing while divisible
  • Whatever remains at the end is prime

docs.title: Basic Factorization Pattern
docs.text:
for (int i = 2; i * i <= n; i++) {
    while (n % i == 0) {
        // i is a prime factor
        n =n/i;
    }
}
if (n > 1) {
    // n itself is a prime factor
}

docs.title: Meaning
docs.text:
The largest number that divides both a and b.

Example:

gcd(12, 18) = 6

docs.title: Euclid’s Algorithm – Intuition
docs.text:
If a divides b, then:

gcd(a, b) = gcd(b, a % b)

We keep shrinking the problem until remainder becomes 0.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
int gcd(int a, int b) {
    while (b>0 && a>0) {
        if(a>b)
        a = a % b;

        if(b>a)
        b=b%a;
    }
    if(a==0)
    return b;
return a;
}

docs.title: Meaning
docs.text: The smallest number divisible by both a and b.

docs.title: Key Relation
docs.text: LCM(a, b) = a×b/GCD(a, b)

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
int lcm(int a, int b) {
    return (a / gcd(a, b)) * b;
}

docs.title: 6. Important Sum Formulas
docs.text:
Used heavily in missing-number and counting problems.

  • Sum of first n numbers:
n(n + 1) / 2
  • Sum of squares:
n(n + 1)(2n + 1) / 6
  • Sum of cubes:
(n(n + 1) / 2)^2

docs.title: Problem Pattern
docs.text: Given numbers from 0 to n with one missing, find it.

docs.title: Intuition
docs.text: We know what the sum should be. We subtract what we actually have.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
int missingNumber(vector<int>& nums) {
    int n = nums.size();
    int expected = n * (n + 1) / 2;
    int sum = 0;
    for (int x : nums)
        sum += x;
    return expected - sum;
}

docs.title: Core Idea
docs.text:
For any number n:

  • Last digit → n % 10
  • Remove digit → n / 10

docs.title: Universal Digit Loop
docs.text:
while (n > 0) {
    int digit = n % 10;
    n = n/10;
}

This single loop powers:

  • Sum of digits
  • Reverse number
  • Palindrome
  • Armstrong
  • Happy number

docs.title: Intuition
docs.text:
Extract digits and rebuild the number from left to right.

int reverse(int n) {
    int rev = 0;
    while (n > 0) {
        int digit = n%10;
        rev = rev * 10 + digit;
        n = n/10;
    }
    return rev;
}

docs.title: Idea
docs.text:
A number is palindrome if:

original == reverse(original)

bool isPalindrome(int n) {
    if (n < 0) return false;
    int original = n, rev = 0;
    while (n > 0) {
        int digit = n%10;
        rev = rev * 10 + digit;
        n = n/10;
    }
    return original == rev;
}

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
A number is Armstrong if:

(sum of each digit ^ number of digits) == number

docs.title: Intuition
docs.text:
• First count digits
  • Then raise each digit to that power
  • Add and compare
bool isArmstrong(int n) {
    int temp = n, count = 0;
    while (temp > 0) {
        count++;
        temp = temp/10;
    }

    int sum = 0;
    temp = n;
    while (temp > 0) {
        int digit = temp % 10;
        sum += pow(digit, count);
        temp /= 10;
    }
    return sum == n;
}

docs.title: Idea
docs.text:
Repeatedly replace number with:

sum of squares of digits

If it becomes 1 → Happy If it repeats → Cycle → Not Happy

docs.title: Why a set?
docs.text:
To detect infinite loops.

int extractDigits(int n) {
    int sum = 0;
    while (n > 0) {
        int d = n % 10;
        sum += d * d;
        n = n/10;
    }
    return sum;
}

bool isHappy(int n) {
    unordered_set<int> seen;
    while (n != 1) {
        if (seen.count(n)) return false;
        seen.insert(n);
        n = extractDigits(n);
    }
    return true;
}

docs.title: Intuition
docs.text:
Instead of checking each number:

  • Assume all are prime
  • Remove multiples of each prime
void sieve(int N) {
    vector<bool> prime(N + 1, true);
    prime[0] = prime[1] = false;

    for (int i = 2; i * i <= N; i++) {
        if (prime[i]) {
            for (int j = i * i; j <= N; j += i)
                prime[j] = false;
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Problem Insight
docs.text:
To form k rows:

coins needed = k(k + 1) / 2

Find the maximum k such that this ≤ n.

int arrangeCoins(int n) {
    long long left = 0, right = n;
    while (left <= right) {
        long long mid = left + (right - left) / 2;
        long long curr = mid * (mid + 1) / 2;
        if (curr == n) return mid;
        if (curr < n) left = mid + 1;
        else right = mid - 1;
    }
    return right;
}

docs.title: 🔑 Final Patterns to Remember
docs.text:
• % 10 and / 10 unlock digit problems
  • Divisors always come in pairs
  • Loop until √n, not n
  • GCD + LCM appear everywhere
  • Mathematical formulas save loops

Master these and DSA math becomes easy 🚀

docs.title: Arrays — 45-Day Plan
docs.text:
Days 1–9

  • [ ] Day 1: Two Sum
  • [ ] Day 2: Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock
  • [ ] Day 3: Contains Duplicate
  • [ ] Day 4: Product of Array Except Self
  • [ ] Day 5: Maximum Subarray
  • [ ] Day 6: 3Sum
  • [ ] Day 7: Container With Most Water
  • [ ] Day 8: Merge Intervals
  • [ ] Day 9: Set Matrix Zeroes

docs.title: Backtracking — 45-Day Plan
docs.text:
Days 43–45

  • [ ] Day 43: Subsets
  • [ ] Day 44: Combination Sum
  • [ ] Day 45: Permutations

docs.title: Dp — 45-Day Plan
docs.text:
Days 40–42

  • [ ] Day 40: Climbing Stairs
  • [ ] Day 41: House Robber
  • [ ] Day 42: Coin Change

docs.title: Graphs — 45-Day Plan
docs.text:
Days 33–36

  • [ ] Day 33: Number of Islands

  • [ ] Day 36: Rotting Oranges

docs.title: Heap — 45-Day Plan
docs.text:
Days 37–39

  • [ ] Day 37: Kth Largest Element in an Array
  • [ ] Day 38: Top K Frequent Elements
  • [ ] Day 39: Merge k Sorted Lists

docs.title: Linkedlists — 45-Day Plan
docs.text:
Days 17–22

  • [ ] Day 17: Reverse Linked List
  • [ ] Day 18: Merge Two Sorted Lists
  • [ ] Day 19: Reorder List
  • [ ] Day 20: Remove Nth Node From End of List
  • [ ] Day 21: Linked List Cycle
  • [ ] Day 22: Add Two Numbers

docs.title: Misc — 45-Day Plan (Supplementary)
docs.text:
Use these as supplementary study items alongside daily tasks:

  • [ ] Bit Manipulation essentials
  • [ ] Math tricks & modulo patterns
  • [ ] Sliding Window patterns roundup
  • [ ] Two Pointers patterns roundup
  • [ ] Greedy technique highlights

docs.title: Stack Queue — 45-Day Plan
docs.text:
Days 23–26

  • [ ] Day 23: Valid Parentheses
  • [ ] Day 24: Min Stack
  • [ ] Day 25: Daily Temperatures
  • [ ] Day 26: Implement Queue using Stacks

docs.title: Strings — 45-Day Plan
docs.text:
Days 10–16

  • [ ] Day 10: Valid Palindrome
  • [ ] Day 11: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters
  • [ ] Day 12: Longest Repeating Character Replacement
  • [ ] Day 13: Valid Anagram
  • [ ] Day 14: Group Anagrams
  • [ ] Day 15: Longest Palindromic Substring
  • [ ] Day 16: Palindromic Substrings

docs.title: Trees — 45-Day Plan
docs.text:
Days 27–32

  • [ ] Day 27: Maximum Depth of Binary Tree
  • [ ] Day 28: Same Tree
  • [ ] Day 29: Invert Binary Tree
  • [ ] Day 30: Binary Tree Level Order Traversal
  • [ ] Day 31: Subtree of Another Tree
  • [ ] Day 32: Balanced Binary Tree

docs.title: Arrays — Solved Problems
docs.text:
Use the TEMPLATE.md in this folder to add solutions.

Recommended filename format: {slug}.md where slug is the problem name.

docs.title: How to add a solution
docs.text:
1. Copy TEMPLATE.md to a new file, e.g., two-sum.md
  2. Fill in title, link, statement summary, approach, and code
  3. Add time/space complexity and notes
